articles.title: Screen Time Vizualization Development
articles.description: Project logs and notes for the development of the Screen Time Vizualization.
articles.contents:
Welcome üëã
The purpose of this site is to host all of the files and notes
related to the development of the Screen Time Vizualization.
Providing Feedback
Providing feedback on interactive documents is tricky. At the bottom
of each page is a giscus comment box.
Comments made here are sent to the discussions
page on GitHub. In order to add comments, you will need to sign in to
GitHub and authorise the giscus app to make
comments on your behalf (don‚Äôt worry, this is safe). Here is my
proposed workflow:
For each piece of feedback or idea, create a new comment.
You can reply to someone else‚Äôs (or your own) comment to keep ideas
together, or upvote it if you think it is a good idea.
You‚Äôll recieve notifications from GitHub (√† la Google Docs) when
someone responds to your comment. You can always turn these off.
To action feedback, I‚Äôll create a GitHub issue linked to the
comment, and respond to the comment when that issue is resolved.
Links üîó
Project Rationale
Contains the rationale for the project and the objectives.
Project
Sketches
These are the early mockups of the design. The focus is mostly on
what idiom best displays the information, rather than on the actual
style and design. That is: ‚Äúis this information clearer as a bar chart
or heatmap?‚Äù, rather than ‚Äúdoes this look good?‚Äù.
Draft App
When an idiom design is finalised, I‚Äôll translate it into a page in a
shiny app. The early builds are meant to be quick, so expect default
styling and clunky interactions. These get resolved once all of the
screens are built.
Repository
All of the code, website pages, feedback, and issues are hosted on
GitHub.
